div.head: ¶Here after foloweth the prologue / To the Ientyll and loueynge readers hereof, That in the merites of Christes passion delyteth.
div.p:
AL ye Ientyll and loueyng readers that in the merytes of Christes passyon delyteth, Note ye only myn intent / and not my rude barbarous tonge / that for lacke of intelligence / may soone vary / from clene & pure eloquence / which for pyte & cōpassion of ye pore baron sinners / yt lyeth strangled in sin, haue interprised in most humble wise / vnderneth your correction, this litle treates to translate / out of ye Latin tonge / into Englyshe Besechyng god of his mercy and
grace, that by ye oft redyng hereof / we may both stablysh our inwarde loue towarde god, & with goostely perceuerans / to ye {per}feccyon of the soule, wherby ye frauwarde and enuyous rankour / of our goostly ennemy the deuill / & the occasyon of syn̄e / may be vtterly subpressed, and the wyll of god and his commaundementes accomplyshed, that cōsequently by ye meanes therof / & throughe the merytes of his most bytter passyon, we may receyue our eternal rewarde / in hys euerlastynge glory & Ioy.

div.head: ¶Here beginneth the communicacōn betwen Ihesu Chryste, and the synner

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p: O My moste benygne lorde Iesu Chryste / haue mercy and pite on me and forgyue thy mooste vnworthyest and vnhappy seruaunt towarde the / wyllynge with the to commune a lyttyll.

sp.speaker: Iesu Chryst.
sp.p: ¶who arte thou / that so lamentably complayneth.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p: ¶A synful man that vnhappely and vnaduysely hath fallen vnto many and dyuers fylthy synnes, ye and from the course of this present lyfe, vnto eternall damnacion, which vnto me is moost vnhappyest and horyble, in tyme to come.

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶Fere thou not this horible decaye and rewen, yf thou wilt vtterly forsake thy sinnes / receyueynge penaunce / with true cōtricyon / makynge satysfaccyon, and neuer here after to offende. Truly I beynge the heuenly glory and inestimable swetnes / descended from my regall trone / of most highest magnyfycence, vnto vnmeasurable dolours & paynes,
whiche gladly I haue suffred in my mynde / in my body & membres / with all sences & partes thereof, to delyuer the frome eternall dampnacyon, & to gyue the my heuenlye inherytaunce & perpetuall glory,

And also doubte thou not / but I wyll clerely forget all thyne offēces / so long as thou arte in wyll & purpose vtterly to forsake thine euyll cōsuetude & custome therof, ye and I saye moreouer / I wyll not remembre thine inequite, but vtterly expell and cause hyt to be so farre indistans from the / as is the mornyng spryng out of the occydent, and I shall mundefye & clense the of thy fylthy synnes, & wyll not leaue ye desolate, before I haue accomplyshed these sayeynges in moost ample wyse.

o. v.Vbi autem habundauit delictū super habundauit et gratia. That is to saye, Truelye where vice & syn hath ben habundant / my grace & mercy farre passed in plenteousnes, there is no armony more delectable or swetter vnto me / then my wyll & commaūdementes to be accomplysshed / with faythfull loue & fyrme hope in my mercy / and with humble teers to pray and byseche me / of thy synnes to be forgyuen.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶O crucyfyed Iesu / I knowe doubtles that I am more derely beloued with yt / then I am with my selfe / For with ye truely I am at all tymes tenderlye beloued / wherof it is wrytten. Diligis
enim oia que sunt et nichil odisti eorum que fecisti.Sa. x Verely thou louyst all thynges and hatyst nothynge that is of thy creacyon. But for as muche as man oftentymes loueth not the / so oftentymes man louethe not hym selfe / wherof the prophet Dauid spekethe.Psal. Qui autem diligit iniquitatem odit animam suam. who that delyteh in vyce and syn abhoreth & hateth his owne soule

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶I haue shewed thys thynge wyth contynuall dolours in all my paynfull lyfe / For truelye I receiued ye crosse of my bytter passyon in ye wombe of my mother / & bare hit continually in my hart & stablyshed hit in my body with
great austerite / wherfore to shew the endles measure of ye hydeous paynes of my soule / I wylled al my mēbres to haue sweten blode and water / in the fynall & instan • ende of my bytter passion / and to reuelate the same whyche before was secretly hid within me from ye wombe of my mother / hit was conuenyent at ye tyme of my deth openlye to be shewed by exteryor sygnes vnto my electe faythefull people.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶O most ientyll Iesu I besech the / beholde and take heede vnto this blody swete / with ye whiche / all thy precyous membres was dyscoloured and made red, And all thy precyous soule tormented most bytterly which remayneth
in all partes of thy gloryous body, and is the conseruacion & lyfe therof, But notwithstādyng my most heuenly lorde / shewe vnto me what thyng thou requerest of me / For all these īestimable paynes that for my sake thou hast so contynually suffred.

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p: ¶Onely loue for loue I axe no more / For truly to purchase & by loue / was ye cause that I suffred myne intollorable passyon.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶O most worthyest lorde with out doubt / thou art most pureste loue / for thou arte of thy nature good in thy selfe / for there maye
none be good but thou onely god For by thy goodenes gracyous lorde, thou delyuerest man / from the seruytude & bondage of oure goostly ennemy the deuyll. And by hit thou remyttyst & forgyuest synne, which thyng no man can doo / but thou lorde god onelye. And also thou louyst theym that loueth the, as ye wyse man in his {pro}uerbes saith.ro. viii Ego diligentes me diligo. And hereist them that denoutlye prayeth & calleth vnto the, As ye prophet Dauid saythe.s. cxiiii Dilexi quoniam exaudiet dominus. That is to say, I haue loued my lorde god, forbecause he wil here my prayer ye and thou good lorde / arte the brennyng charite / whiche vnto ye worlde camest to inflame & moue ye slouthfull & frosty colde hartes
of synners, And thou sayst also. Ego veni vt vitam habeant et habundancius habeant.Ioh. x
I came for synners to haue lyfe ī this worlde by grace and consequently more habundaūce of my glory, in the worlde to come.

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶withoute doubte there is nothyng that so kendeleth ye diuine fyre of charyte, in thy harte, as doth ye kepyng of my commaunddementes, & to ponder well my wordes that now thou haste spoken, And marke well these sayeynges foloweng,Ioh. ii Sic enim deus dilexit mundum vt filium suum vnigenitum daret. That is to saye, God my father, hath so tenderly loued ye worlde, yt for
redempcyon therof, He gaue me his onely sonne, vnto the cruell and most bytter deth of Crosse.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶Truely lord, he is a wretched synner, ī whos hart ye fyre of loue wyll not kendyll, when he consydereth these thynges, wherin appereth the hygh loue and charite of god, O thou onely sonne of god, I besech the, suffer not my poore hart to be frosen or bound, with suche frosty colde, but haue pyte and mercy on me, and gyue me grace that I maye saye these wordes with ye prophet Dauid. Factum est cor meum, tanquam cera liquessens.
•… s. xxi. My harte is molefyed wyth loue, & made as soft as molten waxe.

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶The vnquiet minde of man, toke occasyon of vnkindnes before my passyon, sayeng yt he was created & made, but not as yet redemed, By reason wherof, I am sayd man nomore boūd vnto god, then other creatures, Ne yet there laboreth no more effect in me, then in the brute bestes, But now sayeth the prophet Dauid,Ps. lxii Obstructum est os loquentium iniqua. The wykked mouthes of suche blasfemers be put vnto scylens, and the occasion of such vnkindnes is now voyde & vtterly expelled, Truely I haue laboured more for the redempcyon of mankynde, then in the creacyon of all the worlde, ye forsoth & of a lorde most puesaunt, I was made a seruaunt, and from welth & ryches, I was
torned into pouerte and necessite And of immortall I was made mortall, & of ye wysdome of god, I was made to be incarnate, & of the sonne of god, I was made ye sonne of man, And also I haue suffred the most shamfulest rebukes of proude and approbryous people that euer myght be seene, I haue moreouer mekely suffred crafty and subtell people in theyr dedes, disdayners & repungners agaynst my sayenges, mockers and scorners in my bitter paynes and passyon, pouerte & necessyte of my body / the oryble abhoryng of deth / and the hatefull dyspyce of ye crosse.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶O meruelous & inestymable loue / what may I recompens yt
my lorde god agayne / for all his bytter sorowes / that he hath suffred for me,

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p: ¶If thou wilt remembre howe many thinges I beyng the lorde of hygh magestie / and the onelye sonne of god / hathe suffred for ye, and yf thou woldest gyue thy self to dye a thousande tymes, thou were not able ne yet suffycyent, to recompens me equallye, For ye benygnyte of suche a benefyte lieth out of euery mannes power to requyte,

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
O good lorde / thou saydes here before / yt thou riceyued ye Crosse of thy bytter passion / and bare it contynually / from the wombe of
thy blessed mother, vnto the oure of deth, Therfore I beseche the / shew vnto me those reasons / that caused suche sharpe & bitter paynes, to be alwayes in thy sacred soule, yt hit may be openly knowwen / howe moche I am bounde vnto the / the lorde of glory, that for my sake / thou dyd conclude thy selfe vnto deth, that I maye īioy thi heuēly beatitude / which eye neuer sawe / neere neuer harde,

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶Consider thou diligētly / with a ceruent spryt / & a lyuely hartt / yt for thy sake / and all mankinde, I haue suffred a double marterdome, One in bodye a nother in soule, that thou shulde be accept and taken for the sacrefice of god by true loue and compassyon, all
inflamed with ye loue of charyte / to waste and deuoure thy rusty & kākerd syn, And vnto my corporall merterdome take good hed & beholde, thou shalt se & perceyue that there was neuer passyon of any mertyr so bytter & paynfull, the whiche myght be compared vnto my passyon, and thys wyll I proue vnto the, by auctoryte, by sygne, and by reason, Fyrst I wyll proue vnto yt by auctoryte, That I my selfe crieth out of my grete and inestimable sorowes, by ye mouthe of ye prophet saieng,Trino. 〈…〉
O vos omnes qui transitis {per} viam attendite et videte si est dolor similis sicut dolor meus.

O all ye people that walketh by the way beholde and se, yf theyr be any sorowes lyke vnto my dolorous passyon, as I maye well
verefy there is none. Secondely I wil proue by sygne and token, for theyr was neuer suche sygnes or tokens sene in ye merterdome of any other / as was sene in my passion / and to shew the harde & defficultnes therof / ye sone waxed obscure and darke / and ye erth trymled and quaked / as yf they had taken {per}ceueraūce of a meke compassyon / wyth lamentable cryenges / they bewayled me ye / sonne of god / hāgyng then on ye crosse / for there may no creature suffer or abide my iniury and damage done vnto me his creatour wherī tho wyked & cursed hartes maye be reproued / that wyll not be moued vnto compassion / and sorow of my deth. Thrydly I wyll proue the bytternes of my passyon vnto the by reason / For
thou shalt vnderstande / that my complexcyon / was most noblest in nature / my fleshe vncorrupt / and ye foure elementes that was ioyned vnto it / was most equally deuyded / and moreouer then that / I receyued my pure & clene fleshe of a virgin immaculate / for to avoyde and expell orygynall synne, that is to say / the inordynate concupycence, & with suche a complexcyon / the swete amyable beute / & ye fersnes of strenght alway dothe agre, & in as moche as ye quantytye of euery element / is ye more {pro}porcyonably ioyned to gyther / wherof man is made & create / so moche more difficult & harder is their seperacyon / by this yt apereth by reason / that ye seperacion of my body and soule, was moch more paynfuller then
all other dethes, also how moche more as my fleshe and body was preserued and clere from all orygynall synne, so moche was hyt lykewyse the more paynfuller to be tormented. And as toucheynge my spyrytuall merterdome what I haue suffered ī my soule, thou shalt take good hede / as I haue shewed vnto the before / yt yt began in me / when my soule was fyrste vnyed vnto my body wythin the wombe of the blessed vyrgyn my mother & so alwayes cōtinued from hour to hour and neuer ceased the space of .xxxiii. yeres and aboue / to the tyme my soule was seperate frō my body. And therfore was I constituted & ordeyned a martyr in the wōbe of my blessed mother / wherfore was I neuer without the bytter
martyrdome of my soule not one moment of an houre / for what so euer I suffred / the nyght when I was taken / and in the daye folowyng when I was slayn / of mockes: and scorninges / despisinges and blasfemynges / spyttynges & defyinges / the cronyng of thorne the bitter drynke of eysel and gal the naylynge and stratchynge of my bodye vppon the crosse / all these thynges my blessed sowle susteyned and bore in all my lyfe dayes before / but specially thou oughtest to ponder well in thy mynde and take good hede that the most sharpest darte and most bitter anguyssh of the blessed virgyn my mother was an excessiue cause of all my dolorous paynes in the respecte of all my sorowes For as moche as the degre of her
motherly excellency it besemed to be in perfyte charite / with a feruent loue towarde me her owne chylde / so moche dyde she sorowe and bewayle my bitter paynes & passion / as moche and more then ony liuynge woman myght so do wherfore her most paynfull herte contynually woūded my mynde / in gyuynge newe and fyers bytter tourmentes vnto my soule / throughe her motherly crosse or sorowe. Another cause of my continuall sorowes was all the martyrdomes that euer was / or herafter this shall come vnto my louyng frendes for my sake. wherfore I wyll tell the of trueth that all tho paynes that euery martyr hath suffred in body and soule for my sake / frō Adam vnto the laste man / which at the worldes ende
shall be borne / all these paynes I suffred in my soule without measure / and of very compassion thei wounded and subpressed my hert more deper then all tho corporal paynes yt euer they haue or shall actually suffre in their owne bodyes / and for to verifie the trueth hereof there ben .ii. causes. One is yt I behelde presently all thynges that hath ben created and is created / or shall be created in the clere glasse of my deite. wherfore as soone as my soule was ioyned vnto my body / vnto the tyme I gaue vp my spryt, I began alwayes to beholde all tho paynes that were for to come, bothe vnto me and vnto my louyng frendes whiche mooste cruelly dyde alwayes tourment the inferioure partes of my soule / and of this
thynge specially I was greatly and more greuously payned in my spryt, then euer was or shallbe any of them in their owne propre persons.

Another cause there is that my spyryte was so tormented wyth suche paynes / and that was the abundaunce and superfluite of loue, for loue euer encreaseth and gendreth sorowe and heuines in the spryt / for lyke as mās loue is the more stedfastly and feruently fyxed toward me / so moche more is mās soule tormented with the sorowe of my deth and passion / & for be cause I haue loued the and all men more incomperable then possible ony man may loue him self, therfore I haue suffred more paine in my spryt of all tho thynges then euer any martir hathe
suffred or dothe suffre and shal to the worldes ende. And thou knowest very well that when Paule cōsented vnto ye stonyng & deth of Stephen, & {per}secuted my christen people, I said vnto him. Saule Saule Quid me persequeris.Act. ix Saule Saule why dost thou {per}secute me, and yet did not he persecute me in myn owne propre person, but in ye persons of my electe and chosen frendes. For what so euer is done vnto my frende, be it good or euill, it is done vnto me. And this procedeth of a speciall loue / that I haue vnto man. So therfore thou mayst consider for what cause my passion excelleth in paynes al other that euer hath suffred, or hereafter shall suffre, for because I was tormented bothe in body and in soule, being
pure without sinne / and in a pleasaunt nature, and suffred bothe myne owne martirdome, and also the martirdome of all my elect people al daies of my lyfe. For al suche paines neuer dide perisshe ony of them in their owne propre bodies as it crucified my soule for the space of .xxxiii. yeres and odde wherof the prophet ysay lamently complaineth, crieth and saieth.Esa. liii. Vere langores nostros ipse tulit et dolores not̄s ipse portauit. Doubtles he hath taken on him oure sorowes, and borne on his precious body oure moste greuous paines, and therfore I might neuer laugh, but oftimes wepe, and appered as thoughe I had ben of the age of fyfty yeres and aboue, where I was but xxxiii. yeres and odde, and al caused
the incessant tourmentes and continual dolors that was for to come, both towarde my selfe and my elect people, whiche alwaies clerely I beheld & painfully bore in ye strength of my remēbraunce wherfore I said oftētimes to my fader Multi enī gemit{us} & cor meū merēs.Trino. i My sorowes ben great & my harte is full heuy, and these thinges I shewe vnto the wherby thou shuldest be moued to the more loue & compassion towarde me, for as moche as my life and yeres wasted & cōsumed with sorowes & payne.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶O good Iesu I here very wel perceyue ther is no mans reason may cōpas & sufficiently deserne ye profounde depnes of sorowes & vnmesurable heuines yt alwaies remained in thy sacred soule and
most painful passion, likewise folowed thy moost holy & deuoute body. But natwithstandyng vnderneth my most humble obedience & thy holy wyll nat displesed I moue vnto the one q̄stion meruaylyng moche how any such extreme sorowes or paynes myght in any wyse come to thy blessed soule, when all glory, all ioy & heuenly felicite to it was present & fast knyt & vnyed vnto thy deite / whose amiable beuty & most gloryous countenaūce is so ioyful & aboue all cōparisons in gladnes yt if al ye dāpned soules of hel myght ones behold as doth ye blessed sprytes alway assystyng before ye high maiesty of thy godhed coud neuer suffre tormentes or paynes of any sorow or heuynes by syght of deuilles, or crucifieng ī ye most
sharpest fyre of hell.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p:
¶Euen as thou sayst ther is no doubte, but my soule was & allway is gloryfyed, howe be it my body was mortall & ordeyned to deth. Natwithstādyng my soule after ye superior powers & partes therof was in as hygh glory and ioy frō ye sodeyn momēt or instāt tyme yt it was ioyned to my body bothe then & afterwarde, as well at ye tyme when I honge on the crosse, as whē I descended to hel as I am at this day syttyng at ye ryght syde of my father. But as touchīg ye inferior powers of my soule was ī a cōtynuall {per}ceuerās with an extreme sorow, for ye fore said causes / but by course of nature / suche a meruaylous thynge myght neuer be sene ye ioy & gladnes was euer acōpanyed togider
in one soule, but this thyng was done by meruayl{us} deuine power & miracul{us} {pro}uisiō of my godhed, for after natural cours both ioy & sorow may neuer agre togyther / but euer ye one expelleh ye other / so yt they bothe may neuer remayne ī one place. And for because thou mayst vnderstand these thynges more euidently, I wold thou {per}ceuydest / yt the wel & foūtayne of al my sorowes / was the hyghe & in estimable despēsacion & pardon / of my father, whiche dyd prohibyt and forbed the influence or fluxe of the glorye of my deite, whiche remayned in the superiour powers of my soule / that in no wyse shuld redowne vnto the inferioure partes therof. For without suche prouision / it were vnpossible my soule coulde euer
haue suffred any payne or sorow but because this fluxe or influence was clerely prohibyt in me / therfore I dyde parfetely rest in Ioye and glorye / after the superiour partes. And after the inferiour partes therof / I was most vehemently crucified with intollerable paynes, And so the paternall power of my father conioyned miraculously the moste depest sorowe / with moste highest swetnes / & ye most highest power with ye most wekest infirmite / forbecause this flux or īfluēce was {pro}hibit in me / & yt passed the course of nature / for by natural course ye superior powers of ye soule ought to norysshe & fede ye īferiour partes. And in as moche as this despēsacion and pardon was the more marueylous
ordeyned / my payn and sorowes was the more sharpe and bytter. Also thou shalte vnderstande, that in all my feruent paynes & passion I obserued & kept my natural course vnto my last ende of deth, wherby I suffred the more paynes and sorowes.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶without doubt good lorde / he is worthy of deth that refuseth to lyue with the eternally, whiche hathe gyuen thy lyfe for vs / and he yt lyuethe is but a deed man, that wyll not bothe represent in hym selfe the remembraunce of thy moste bytter and contynuall passyon and alwaye bere on his body thy sore & greuous woundes, by doyenge sharpe & strayte penaunce / and also wyll not crucifye hym selfe in hys paynefull
harte / and prepayre & make vnto hym selfe a tourment of depressyng carnall affeccion & voluptuous pleasure.

sp.speaker: Christe.
sp.p: ¶Si quis vult venire post me abneget semet ipm ipsum & tollat crucē suā quotidie & sequat̄ me.Ma. xv yt is to say / he yt wyll come after me / let hym take on him his crosse & always folow me.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p: ¶O mercifull Iesu yt arte ye profoūde wisdom & excellent vertue of god / illumyne my soule with ye gyft of vnderstandyng, yt I may perceyue thy wordes.

sp.speaker: Christe.
sp.p:
¶In this my words thou shalt vnderstande, yt vnto reasonable man which is made as ye ymage of god, I haue prouided .iii. thynges / yt is bondshyp / vyle & sharpe sorow, in forsakīg hī self apereth
bondshyp / in beryng of his crosse is vilete & shame / in folowīg me betokeneth bytt̄ sorow. who yt falleth by inobedience frō ye state of iii. felicites must hūbly aryse by ye obediēce of .iii. miserable afflyctions. Treuly he falleth frō ye associacion and felyshyp of angelles & frō ye clere vision & fruicion of my deite & frō ye heuenly btītude, therfore let him here my coūsell & folowe the same, yt in forsakynge him selfe / whiche dothe sygnifye his propre wyll, he shall recouer his free lyberte. And in takynge on hī his crosse, that is for to suffre gladly to be contempned and despised of other / he shal recouer the heuenly felyshyp and cōpany of angelles / and in folowyng me that is the steppes of my passion by chastning of his body, he shal
recouer the clere vision of my godhed.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p: ¶Verily good lorde, it is mete and conuenient ye and also necessary, who yt wyll reygne with the in glory and ioye, they shuld with the lykewise suffre sorowe & tribulacion, and tho that wyl be norysshed with thy moost blessed coūtenaunce ought to folow thy bytter passion.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p:
Happye is this sentēce or Iudgemēt of thy mouth, but blessed & more happyer is he yt always doth reuolue in his mynde & remembre perfytly how strayt and narowe and how bitter and sharpe is the waye that conducet man to eternall lyfe, whenne it besemed me for too suffre suche sorowes before I my selfe myght entre my
glory, yf I in suche wyse bought myne owne propre glory, who is he that may or shall haue it frely by due ryght and tytle, with pastyme & pleasure. wherfore there is none otherway vnto the kyngdome of heuen, but by payne & labour. And yt ryche man which wyll not chasten his body here, with labour & payne, in ye respect of penaunce: he shall be associat with ye deuyll in paynes. And ye poore man truly with payne and labour in this myserable lyfe: seketh ye crowne of eternall glorye.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶Alas & wo be vnto me moste synful man, yt more delited in carnall affection and more was deceyued by vanyte of this worlde then to folow the, whiche oftentymes for pyte of me, dydest very
bytterly wepe & wayle / & as I haue rede thy blessed mother & virgyn īmaculate / dyd ones ioye / in syngyng her canticle.Luce. i •…
But o how oftentymes dyd ye sharpe sworde of sorowe wounde and perce her holy soule.Luc. i •…
And also Iohn̄ Baptyst ye exempler & leder of penaūs ones dyd ioy within ye wombe of his moder which oftētymes is to be supposed / dyd lamentably sorowe with an heuy harte.

sp.speaker: Chryste.
sp.p:
¶I hangyng on the crosse / dyd promyse {per}adice to none but vnto theym beynge on the crosse with me.Gala. 〈…〉
They hangeth on the crosse yt crucifieth their flessh with vice & cōcupiscens Also I prayed on ye crosse only for neglygēt synners & not for wylfull synners, truely
as longe as theye be so theye be crucified, without clyppynge or brasinge of me, for I the whiche instretched myne armes on the crosse / enbrased & byclypped all those for whom I suffred my passyon. if therfore thou wilt ascend after me / and ī heuen with me to be resident / it besemeth thou folowe me by the way of the crosse / by the which I haue entred into my glorye. Thou canst not trust vnto a better way then to folowe the same wherin I haue gone before. Truly yf thou stray or wander from my steppes / thou shalte peryssh for euermore. Take diligent hede that thou perceyue in what way thou mayst ascende in to heuē. I without dout comyng vnto this worlde descended by a ladder hauyng .iii. steppes & yt is
humilite / pouerte & payne / wherof it is rede in holy scripture.

¶Inuenietis infantem pannis inuolutum et positum in precepio.Luc. ii That is to saye / ye shal fynde a lytel chyld ful poore & nedy / wrapped with clothes of sorowe / & lyinge in a maūger / & by these .iii. degrees I returned afterwarde vnto heuen agayne. These steppes my valiant apostell Paule cōsidereth & noteth in me / where as he writeth.Phi. ii Exinaniuit semet ipm ipsum . That is to say / he hath forsaken him selfe. Here mayst thou beholde in me / ye degre of pouerte,Phi. ii Formam accipiens And taken on hym the offyce of a seruaunt. Here mayst thou beholde in me the degree of humilitie.Phi. ii Factus obediēs vs{que} ad mortem. And made obediēt
vnto dethe. Beholde here is in me the degree of bytter sorowe / but whyther dothe this ladder of thre steppes cōduce and lede me harken what foloweth.
•… hi. ii. Propter {quod} et deus illum exaltauit et dedit illi nomen: {quod} est super omne nomen. For because of that, god hath bothe exalted hym and gyuen vnto hym suche name that passeth al names. Therfore they be fooles and worse then madde that wyll ascende vnto heuen after me, by a ladder hauynge cōtrary degrees or steppes / that is to saye / by ryches / honours / and pleasures of the worlde / for as these thynges ledeth man vnto infernall paynes: soo dothe the fyrst conduce man vnto heuen.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p: ¶O lorde it is a meruaylous abusyon / for a seruaunt to rest & make good chere / and the lorde to suffre payne and take great laboure.

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶who that deuoutly wyll remembre my passyon / let hym be a shamed to folowe the pleasure and voluptuousnes of the body, for the remembraunce of my passyon dothe torment and expell al vice and synne / for in my passion all men may contempne the pleasure of the worlde and the flesshe whiche yf thou wylte ouercome without laboure thou oughtest deuoutly remembre my passyon / and in ye same ioyously to delyte and styck surely to my woundes ye and yf thou wylte ouercome &
resyst the deuyll / whiche syngulerly dothe persecute vertuous & well disposed people / and to subpresse him from his crafty wylynes / thou oughtest alwayes to remembre my heuy passion. But it is necessary and cōuenyent / that they imprynt and marke the carecter and similitude of my passyon in their maners and conuersacyon / ye whiche dothe imprynt or marke for theyr defence, the sygne and token of my passion in their forehedes, & that they lyue vnderneth the lawe of me, with whose fayth they be armed Otherwyse suche falsely bereth the carecter of my father, whose commaundementes they wyll not folowe ne yet obserue. And also suche be not safely defended by the crosse of me, whose sorofull paynes
they wyll not consyder.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p: ¶O meke Iesu be thou mercyfull and gracyous / in geuynge a more larger confort or ioye vnto my herynge, by shewynge vnto me moste wretched synner / ye profytes & frutes yt cometh by dayly remembraūce of thy moste holy passyon.

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶The remēbraūce of my dethe oft by dayly ruminaciō / to flame and burne in the auter of thy remembraunce for many causes. The first cause is: thou mayst do no thynge that more delyteth or pleaseth me / then to exercyse thy hart with loue / cōpassyon / in honouryng & folowyng my passion of the whiche no doubt there is: but it dothe appere in many auctorytes
of holy scripture. And for sothe I warne the to prynte and marke in thy soule my tēder loue and amorous paynes / & for the same thou gyue me herty thankes / & as a sygne or token thou put & ioyne me vpon thy hart: as yf I sayd. Loue me as I loue ye. Remembre thou not onely what thynges I haue made vnto the / but howe bytter & vyle thynges I haue suffred for ye. And yf thou loue me not / thou art myne enemy. And therfore take hede & cōsyder thou do not me offende. who is he truely dothe loue the as I do. who is he that so desyreth to be beloued with ye as I do. Therfore after this / put me on thy hart as a sygne or tokē thou louest me with al thy strength / & on thyne armes that thou mayst
perfourme with all thy loue tho thynges which be pleasaūt vnto me. And within thy harte yt thou mayst subpresse all thynges in this worlde / that vnto ye is pleasaunt in thy loue / and prefer me euermore aboue al thynges / and that thou alwayes loue me more and more. The seconde is: thou oughtest feruently to remembre my passyon / for thou mayst haue by it a perfyte gyde vnto my deuyne loue. Truly by my passyon I haue shewed my quantyte of loue vnto the. wherfore thou oughtest to consyder that loue deserueth & requyreth loue agayne And more ouer take good heed what I wyll say vnto the. I neuer wylled to haue redemed mā by prayer or intercessyon / for so mought man quyckely delyuer
man from captiuite / ne yet also by the pryce of golde or syluer / for in suche wyse be the rewde bestes: as shepe or oxen redemed and bought. But ye conclusyō of mannes redempcyon / was determined to be bought with ye pryce of my precious bloode / that my loue shulde hange alwayes in the pryce of the thynge yt is bought: leest therfore thou shuldest vylepend and not regarde thyne 〈◊◊〉 Consider thou quyckely the pryce of thy selfe / for if I shulde haue redemed mā with golde or syluer / it mought haue ben supposed the soule of man were to be compared with worldely ryches / for that thynge whiche is bought or redemed is farre more precious / then that thyng by the which it is bought
or redemed. And therfore is thy soule more precio{us} thē my blode ¶Thyrdely is for the excitynge of deuocion / wherof a fygure is rede / that Sampson founde a hony combe within the mouthe of a deed Lyon. This Lyon am I, of the trybe of Iude in whose mouth ye swete honi combe of deuocion, was foūde by yt which ye spiryt of man is refresshed & meruaylously conforted. O yf thou tokest good hede / thou woldest consyder / and perfytely ponder how petifully my mouth opened and semed halfe on lyue & halfe deed / and my tongue was deformed with gore bloode, ye and I dare well saye / yf thy harte were as harde as is the steele, this thynge well pondered and remēbred, it shulde be made lyquyet
with compassyon and deuocion. The fourth frute of the remembraūce of my passion is, because in it is founde a sure defence agaynste all enemyes. wherof my apostel Pet{er} doth say.Pet. iiii.
Xpo Christo igit̄ passo in carne et vos eadem cogitatiōe armamini. Christ therfore hath suffred deth & passion incarnate / yt by ye remēbraūce therof loke ye arme your self / & as ysayas reherseth lykewise.
•… ye. ii. In gredere ī petram. As a kynge that is not able to withstande his enemyes in the felde, taketh socour of the castel. So entre ye into the stone whyche am I: of whome the Prophet speketh of. For an ennemye shall neuer preuayle agaynst him in whome the dayly batayle of my passion alway delyteth.

The fyfth is because man onely is restored vnto his merytes by none other maner of meanes but by the remembraunce of my passyon / for the foundement of all grace and the roote of meryte cōsysteth in the doloure of my hart and crucyfyinge of my body / the whiche my electe postell sayth. Non enim iudicaui me scire aliquid inter vos nisi Iesū Christū et hunc crucifixum.Cor. ii Truely I haue nat iudged or determyned to knowe any thynge of my selfe amongest you: but my lord Iesu Chryste & that he was crucyfyed. And also Bernarde the deuoute chylde of my blessed mother lyke wyse sayeth.Barndus. Sūma philosophia mea inqd inquid est scire christum Iesū et hunc crucifixum. My most high lernyng and vnderstāding
he saith is for to know Iesu christ & yt he was crucyfyed. But for as moche as there be so many ennemyes vnto my crosse / thou oughtest to be heuy & sory / with a lamentable harte / for the voluptuous lyuers of thys myserable worlde be my persecutours and folowers of my deth / nat as fauters and aucters to the same but as despysers and contempters therof. That wylfully excludeth and auoydeth from theym / the merytes of my passyon and causeth them self to be vnworthy of my heuenly benedictiō and ineffable glory / and wyl in no wyse conuerte vnto me / but alwayes contynue in pleasure and delyte of body / suche nat onely mocketh and scorneth the merites of my passyon, but also tredeth me the
sone of god vnderneth their fete, and taketh disdayne of my spyrytuall grace, for a carnall lyfe is iniurye vnto god. A malycyous despyte vnto my crosse / and prouoketh shame and rebuke vnto all the hole Trynite.

The syxth is yt the remembraūce of my passyon causeth all paynes and labours / to be glad and ioyfull that synners taketh in ye way of penaunce and the exercyse of a godly and a relygyous lyfe, for truely a deuout knyght neuer feleth his owne sorowes or paynes what tyme he perceyuethe and beholdeth the sore plages and woūdes of his gentyll lorde and duke. The seuenth is that my passyon called vnto remēbraūce quencheth & vtterly banyssheth all carnall concupyscence. For
with out doubte the syght of my passyō wedreth and dryeth what so euer thynge foloweth man of a carnal desyre. The eyght causeth exercyse of compungcyon & penaūce doynge, in recompence of synnes, for who is he that wyl nat wayle and sorow in most largest wyse, knowyng that his synnes be so odyous and hatefull in the syght of god my father, that for the purgeyng therof, he wylled me his electe sonne / to suffre moost paynefull deth and passyō on the crosse. The nyneth causeth multyplyenge & increasyng of good fayth and hope, for a synner hath refuge by my crosse / as a thefe or homicyde hathe by a church or cymitory. There is nothynge to that dethe, that by my deth may nat recouer. I haue
chaunged the sentence of eternal dampnacyon, by crucyfying my body. For in that sentence which Pylate gaue agaynst me. I toke on me ye combrous weyght and burden of all synnes, and was iudged vnto deth for all synners to discharge and vtterly expulse their fylthy sinnes, with ye which they were long tyme before, sore pestred and accombred. wherfore now accordyng vnto thy desyre I haue shewed and declared the goostly frutes that foloweth by deuout remembraunce of my sorowfull passyon.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p:
¶O good Iesu I now perceyue and vnderstande very wel, these thynges thou hast rehersed, how be it this sentence gyuen by Pylate
was very peruers and cruel towarde the, and therfore it was detestable to be abhorred / for as moche as man hathe no power vpon god / ne yet a corrupt lyuer vpon ye iust and rightuous man. Neuertheles as touchynge for mannes redempcion it was meruaylous profytable and fruteful and therfore it was through thy prouysyon very louynge & moste venerable, for as moche as it clerely reuoked the foresayde iugement or sentence pronoūced and declared for ye fyrst synne of man For that open sentence of excludynge or banysshynge was full of sorowe and heuynes.

wherof it is wrytten Emisit eū dominus de{us} de paradiso voluptatis.
〈…〉 . iii. &c. et collocauit ante paradisū voluptatis cherubin et flameū
gladiū at{que} versatilē ad custodiendā viā ligni vite. Our lorde expulsed man out from paradyce, of heuenly pleasure and assygned, the anugell Cherubyn, with an armyng sworde, to kepe the way vnto ye tree of lyfe. But nowe happy and blessed is thy sentence wherby the exyle, man is called & restored agayne vnto ye celestiall paradyce when by this sentence the sone of god wrongfully was caste out from his inherytaunce as a seruaunt: tyllyng and plowyng the vyneyarde of Moyses lawe. wherof the apostell speketh. Iesus vt scīficaret {per} suum sanguinē populum extra portam passus est.Heb. xii Because that Iesus wold halow and sanctifye his people by his precyous bloode, he suffred deth
without ye gate. And well it may so be said that he suffred without to brynge vs within the gate of heuen. For without doubt we haue onely oure entrynge in, by shedynge of his precyous blood But o mekest Iesu in most humblest wyse, I beseche the with ye feruent powers of my hart, and for all the bytter sorowes and in tollerable passion with ye whiche thy most dulce and pleasant hart was persed and wounded: as with most kynnest and sharpest dartes / ye and also I beseche the for all ye sorowes that thy blessed mother and virgyn immaculate susteyned and suffred, in beholdynge thy tormentes and passiō and in especially what tyme she harde of the cruel sentence of thy condēpnacyon vnto deth / turne
towarde me thy mercyfull countenaunce / and of pyte and compassyon delyuer me poore synner in the hour of deth / and in the extreme day of iugement / frō ye terible wordes and sentence of eternall dampnacyon / whiche thou shalt sounde out with a huge & a fereful voyce vnto al reproued synners sayinge. Descedite a me maledicti in ignem eternum:Ma. xxv qui parat{us} est diabolo & angelis eius. That is to say departe & get ye hens moste wycked & cursed synners vnto the eternal fyre of hell whiche is prepared and redy for the deuyll and all his angelles.

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶Blessed & happy is that man whiche alway bereth in remembraunce
his fynall iugemēt that by the fere and drede / wherof he may withdrawe his lyfe frome the deceytfull pleasures of this world / & without doubt this iugmēt or sētence is to be fered wherat al thīgs shalbe opē & manifestly knowē without witnes & all ye hole multitude & cōpany both of angels & holy saītes shalbe their {pre}sent & eūi creature shal trimble for feare before my hygh maiesty & iudiciall seate. But what shall they say then yt in this lytel tyme hath so folysshly & so neglygētly lyued / to whom my saying shalbe in this maner. I haue truely loked for you pacyently / & haue very ientely prayed & desyred all you vnto my kīgdom / & for your neclygens I now requyre of you a coūtes & more ouer I say vnto
you / yt for youre sakes I toke on me ye feblenes of natur & was cōuersant vpon ye erth. And for you was I flagellat & scorged in my body / for you was I lykewyse mocked & scorned & al be spotted & vtterly defyed & for you I was spytefully beaten & buffed about my face with vnclene fystes & hādes. For you also I was vniustly condempned vnto deth / & for you I was crucifyed in my body & hanged on ye crosse / & fed with bitter gal & eysel. And al this suffred I to make you holi & blessed saītes. I haue more ouer named & called all you my dere brethren I haue offred al you vnto my father. I haue sende vnto you the spryt of god. I haue opened vnto you my paradyce of glory. what ought I more to haue don
& haue not perfourmed the same in very dede for your saluacyon Answere vnto me ye wretched synners. what haue ye suffred for me your lorde & gouerner which beynge pure & clene hath suffred so moche for you. Truely these shalbe the repeticions made at ye dredfull day of iugement.

sp.speaker: The synner.
sp.p: ¶Alas that euer I was conceyued or borne / howe miserable a wretche am I: what may I say / or what shall I do / in yt dredfull day / whē at my apperaūce I can performe no maner of goodnes before the most ferefull iudge.

sp.speaker: Chryst.
sp.p:
¶whyles ye tyme dureth correct thy lyfe / chaunge thy maners /
ouercome euyll temptacions / by manfully resystynge / punysshe thy carkes and pray with lowly teeres / thy synnes hath the here as a conquerour or a punyssher, that thou mayst ī yt day haue me nat as a iudge, but as a sauyour yf thou therfore faythfully performe these thīges rehersed thou shalt be saued in that daūgerous day, without any fere that ye multytude of thy synnes / shall put ye vnto. For soth I am a more mercyfull sauyoure then thou arte a synner, thy synnes be great but my mercy is infynite / yf thou be a synner / I am the meke lambe of god which hath taken away ye synnes of the worlde / and came nat for to cal iust lyuers, but synners vnto penaunce. For truely thou shalt fynde in me more mercy
and loue then thou da • est boldely aske or desy • e.

div.p: ¶Thus endeth the Dialogue or communicacion betwene our sauiour Ihesu Chryste and a sinner / lately translated out of the Latin tonge in to englyshe, And newly imprynted, at London in south warke by Iohan Redman, For Robert Redman, Cum priuilegio.
